excite.translation[0].definitions[0].def: to make someone feel happy, interested, or eager
excite.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: His playing is technically brilliant, but it doesn’t excite me.
excite.translation[0].definitions[1].def: to cause a particular feeling or reaction
excite.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: The court case has excited a lot of public interest.
He tried not to do anything to excite the suspicion of the police.
The book excited very little comment.
excite.translation[0].definitions[2].def: to make someone feel sexual desire
excite.translation[0].definitions[3].def: to make an organ, nerve etc in your body react or increase its activity
excite.translation[0].note_box[0].headin: – Meaning 2: to cause a particular feeling or reaction
excite.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: She is a talented young actress who has excited a lot of interest.
Rumours of hidden treasure excited our curiosity.
She sought to excite the jury's sympathy at every possible opportunity.
The government's proposals have excited anger among teachers.
He accused sections of the media of trying to excite racial hatred.
The figures are unlikely to excite any reaction on the money markets.
The film excited a lot of favourable comments, both here and in America.
The photographs excited rumours that their marriage is over.
The cut in US interest rates excited speculation of a similar cut in the UK.
excite.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to produce a lot of activity in a market, with a lot of people buying and selling stocks and shares
excite.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: The auditors excited the market again yesterday by reporting sharply higher profits for the group.
